<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    restricted stock units for which future service is required as a
    condition to the delivery of the underlying common stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Cash and Cash
    Equivalents</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm defines cash equivalents as highly liquid overnight
    deposits held in the ordinary course of business.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Recent
    Accounting Developments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>FIN&#160;No.&#160;48.</B>&#160;In June 2006, the FASB issued
    FIN&#160;No.&#160;48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
    Taxes&#160;&#151;&#160;an Interpretation of FASB Statement
    No.&#160;109.&#148; FIN&#160;No.&#160;48 requires that the firm
    determine whether a tax position is more likely than not to be
    sustained upon examination, including resolution of any related
    appeals or litigation processes, based on the technical merits
    of the position. Once it is determined that a position meets
    this recognition threshold, the position is measured to
    determine the amount of benefit to be recognized in the
    financial statements. The firm will adopt the provisions of
    FIN&#160;No.&#160;48 in the first quarter of 2008. Adoption of
    FIN&#160;No.&#160;48 will not have a material effect on the
    firm&#146;s financial condition, results of operations or cash
    flows.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157.</B>&#160;In September 2006, the FASB
    issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157, &#147;Fair Value
    Measurements.&#148; SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 clarifies that fair
    value is an exit price, representing the amount that would be
    received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an
    orderly transaction between market participants. Under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157, fair value measurements are not adjusted
    for transaction costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 nullifies the guidance included in EITF
    Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;02-3,</FONT>
    &#147;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts
    Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy
    Trading and Risk Management Activities,&#148; that prohibited
    the recognition of a day one gain or loss on derivative
    contracts (and hybrid financial instruments measured at fair
    value under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;155) where the firm was unable to
    verify all of the significant model inputs to observable market
    data <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    verify the model to market transactions. However,
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 requires that a fair value measurement
    reflect the assumptions market participants would use in pricing
    an asset or liability based on the best information available.
    Assumptions include the risks inherent in a particular valuation
    technique (such as a pricing model)
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT> the
    risks inherent in the inputs to the model.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 prohibits the recognition of
    &#147;block discounts&#148; for large holdings of unrestricted
    financial instruments where quoted prices are readily and
    regularly available for an identical asset or liability in an
    active market.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The provisions of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 are to be applied
    prospectively, except changes in fair value measurements that
    result from the initial application of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 to
    existing derivative financial instruments measured under EITF
    Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;02-3,</FONT>
    existing hybrid financial instruments measured at fair value and
    block discounts, all of which are to be recorded as an
    adjustment to beginning retained earnings in the year of
    adoption.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm adopted SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157 as of the beginning of
    2007. The transition adjustment to beginning retained earnings
    was a gain of $51&#160;million, net of tax. For the first
    quarter of 2007, the effect of the nullification of EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;02-3</FONT>
    and the removal of liquidity discounts for actively traded
    positions was not material. In addition, under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157, gains on principal investments are
    recorded in the absence of substantial third-party transactions
    if market evidence is sufficient. In the first quarter of 2007,
    the firm recorded approximately $500&#160;million of such gains
    as a result of adopting SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    123
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158.</B>&#160;In September 2006, the FASB
    issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting
    for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans, an
    amendment of FASB Statements No.&#160;87, 88, 106 and
    132-R.&#148; SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 requires an entity to
    recognize in its statement of financial condition the funded
    status of its defined benefit pension and postretirement plans,
    measured as the difference between the fair value of the plan
    assets and the benefit obligation. SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 also
    requires an entity to recognize changes in the funded status of
    a defined benefit pension and postretirement plan within
    accumulated other comprehensive income, net of tax, to the
    extent such changes are not recognized in earnings as components
    of periodic net benefit cost. SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 is
    effective as of the end of the fiscal year ending after
    December&#160;15, 2006. The firm adopted SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158
    as of the end of 2007. The adjustment to accumulated other
    comprehensive loss for the initial application of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158 was $194&#160;million, net of tax.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159.</B>&#160;In February 2007, the FASB
    issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159, &#147;The Fair Value Option for
    Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities,&#148; which gives
    entities the option to measure eligible financial assets,
    financial liabilities and firm commitments at fair value (i.e.,
    the fair value option), on an
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">instrument-by-instrument</FONT>
    basis, that are otherwise not accounted for at fair value under
    other accounting standards. The election to use the fair value
    option is available at specified election dates, such as when an
    entity first recognizes a financial asset or financial liability
    or upon entering into a firm commitment. Subsequent changes in
    fair value must be recorded in earnings. Additionally,
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159 allows for a one-time election for
    existing positions upon adoption, with the transition adjustment
    recorded to beginning retained earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm adopted SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159 as of the beginning of
    2007 and elected to apply the fair value option to the following
    financial assets and liabilities existing at the time of
    adoption:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    certain unsecured short-term borrowings, consisting of all
    promissory notes and commercial paper;
</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    certain other secured financings, primarily transfers accounted
    for as financings rather than sales under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140
    and debt raised through the firm&#146;s William Street program;
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>

</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The transition adjustment to beginning retained earnings related
    to the adoption of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159 was a loss of
    $45&#160;million, net of tax, substantially all of which related
    to applying the fair value option to prepaid physical commodity
    transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Subsequent to the adoption of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159, the firm
    has elected to apply the fair value option (i)&#160;to new
    positions within the above categories, (ii)&#160;to corporate
    loans, corporate loan commitments and certificates of deposit
    issued by GS Bank USA and (iii)&#160;generally to investments
    where the firm would otherwise apply the equity method of
    accounting. In certain cases, the firm may continue to apply the
    equity method of accounting to those investments which are
    strategic in nature or closely related to the firm&#146;s
    principal business activities, where the firm has a significant
    degree of involvement in the cash flows or operations of the
    investee,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT> where
    cost-benefit considerations are less significant.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The primary reasons for electing the fair value option are
    mitigating volatility in earnings from using different
    measurement attributes, simplification and cost-benefit
    considerations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B><FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-1</FONT>
    and FSP
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R-7.</FONT></B>&#160;In
    June 2007, the American Institute of Certified Public
    Accountants (AICPA) issued Statement of Position (SOP)
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;07-1,</FONT>
    &#147;Clarification of the Scope of the Audit and Accounting
    Guide &#145;Audits of Investment Companies&#146; and Accounting
    by Parent Companies and Equity Method Investors for Investments
    in Investment Companies.&#148;
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-1</FONT>
    clarifies when an entity may apply the provisions of the Audit
    and Accounting Guide for Investment Companies (the Guide). In
    May 2007, the FASB issued FSP
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R-7,</FONT>
    &#147;Application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;46-R</FONT>
    to Investment Companies,&#148; which amends
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R</FONT>
    to make permanent the temporary deferral of the application of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R</FONT>
    to entities within the scope of the revised Guide under
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-1.</FONT>
    FSP
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R-7</FONT>
    is effective upon adoption of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-1.</FONT>
    In November 2007, the FASB issued Proposed FSP
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-1-a,</FONT>
    &#147;The Effective Date of AICPA Statement of Position
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">07-1,&#148;</FONT>
    which proposes to indefinitely defer the effective date for
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;No.&#160;07-01</FONT>
    and, consequently, FSP
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">FIN&#160;No.&#160;46-R-7.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11.</FONT></B>&#160;In
    June 2007, the EITF reached consensus on Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11,</FONT>
    &#147;Accounting for Income Tax Benefits of Dividends on
    Share-Based Payment Awards.&#148; EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11</FONT>
    requires that the tax benefit related to dividend equivalents
    paid on restricted stock units, which are expected to vest, be
    recorded as an increase to additional paid-in capital. The firm
    currently accounts for this tax benefit as a reduction to income
    tax expense. EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11</FONT>
    is to be applied prospectively for tax benefits on dividends
    declared in fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15, 2007,
    and the firm expects to adopt the provisions of EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11</FONT>
    beginning in the first quarter of 2009. The firm is currently
    evaluating the impact of adopting EITF Issue
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;06-11</FONT>
    on its financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    125
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Note&#160;3.&#160;&#160;Financial
    Instruments</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Fair Value of
    Financial Instruments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the firm&#146;s financial
    instruments owned, at fair value, including those pledged as
    collateral, and financial instruments sold, but not yet
    purchased, at fair value. At any point in time, the firm may use
    cash instruments as well as derivatives to manage a long or
    short risk position.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-left: 6%; margin-right: 0%">

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 5%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Includes $6.17&#160;billion and
    $6.93&#160;billion as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively, of money market instruments held by William Street
    Funding Corporation to support the William Street credit
    extension program (see Note&#160;6 for further information
    regarding the William Street program).
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(2)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Includes $7.64&#160;billion of
    mortgage whole loans that were transferred to securitization
    vehicles where such transfers were accounted for as secured
    financings rather than sales under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140. The
    firm distributed to investors the securities that were issued by
    the securitization vehicles and therefore does not bear economic
    exposure to the underlying mortgage whole loans.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(3)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Net of cash received pursuant to
    credit support agreements of $59.05&#160;billion and
    $24.06&#160;billion as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(4)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Includes $1.17&#160;billion of
    securities held within the firm&#146;s insurance subsidiaries
    which are accounted for as
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    under SFAS&#160;No. 115, &#147;Accounting for Certain
    Investments in Debt and Equity Securities&#148; as of November
    2007. Includes $9.95&#160;billion of securities held within GS
    Bank USA and the firm&#146;s insurance subsidiaries which were
    accounted for as available-for-sale as of November 2006.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Net of cash paid pursuant to credit
    support agreements of $27.76&#160;billion and
    $16.00&#160;billion as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 1%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Fair Value
    Hierarchy</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following tables set forth by level within the fair value
    hierarchy &#147;Financial instruments owned, at fair
    value,&#148; &#147;Financial instruments sold, but not yet
    purchased, at fair value&#148; and financial assets and
    liabilities accounted for at fair value under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;155 and SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159 as of November
    2007 (see Note&#160;2 for further information on the fair value
    hierarchy). As required by SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157, assets and
    liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest
    level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total financial assets at fair value classified within
    level&#160;3 were $69.15&#160;billion or 6% of &#147;Total
    assets&#148; on the consolidated statement of financial
    condition as of November 2007. This includes $14.44&#160;billion
    of financial assets at fair value classified within level&#160;3
    for which the firm does not bear
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    126
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    economic exposure. Excluding assets for which the firm does not
    bear economic exposure, level&#160;3 assets were 5% of
    &#147;Total assets&#148; as of November 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 5%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=456 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="7%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Consists of transfers accounted for
    as secured loans rather than purchases under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140 and prepaid variable share forwards.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(2)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Reflects securities borrowed within
    Trading and Principal Investments. Excludes securities borrowed
    within Securities Services, which are accounted for based on the
    amount of cash collateral advanced plus accrued interest.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(3)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Consists of level&#160;3 assets
    which are financed by nonrecourse debt, attributable to minority
    investors or attributable to employee interests in certain
    consolidated funds.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(4)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Consists of U.S. Treasury
    securities and money market instruments as well as insurance
    separate account assets measured at fair value under AICPA
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">SOP&#160;03-1,</FONT>
    &#147;Accounting and Reporting by Insurance Enterprises for
    Certain Nontraditional Long-Duration Contracts and for Separate
    Accounts.&#148;
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(5)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Principally consists of securities
    borrowed and resale agreements. The underlying securities have
    been segregated to satisfy certain regulatory requirements.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(6)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Consists of private equity and real
    estate fund investments.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top"><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(7)</FONT></SUP></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Represents cash collateral and the
    impact of netting across the levels of the fair value hierarchy.
    Netting among positions classified within the same level is
    included in that level.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    <BR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 6%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=456 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Consists of promissory notes, commercial paper and hybrid
    financial instruments.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(2)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Consists of certificates of deposit issued by GS Bank USA.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(3)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Reflects securities loaned within Trading and Principal
    Investments. Excludes securities loaned within Securities
    Services, which are accounted for based on the amount of cash
    collateral received plus accrued interest.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(4)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Primarily includes transfers accounted for as financings rather
    than sales under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140 and debt raised through
    the firm&#146;s William Street program.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(5)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Primarily includes hybrid financial instruments and prepaid
    physical commodity transactions.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(6)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Represents cash collateral and the impact of netting across the
    levels of the fair value hierarchy. Netting among positions
    classified within the same level is included in that level.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Level&#160;3
    Gains and Losses</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets forth a summary of changes in the fair
    value of the firm&#146;s level&#160;3 financial assets and
    liabilities for the year ended November 2007. The table reflects
    gains and losses for the full year for all financial assets and
    liabilities categorized as level&#160;3 as of November 2007. The
    table does not include gains or losses that were reported in
    level&#160;3 in prior periods for financial assets and
    liabilities that were transferred out of level&#160;3 prior to
    November 2007. As reflected in the table below, the net
    unrealized gain on level&#160;3 financial assets and liabilities
    was $1.31&#160;billion for the year ended November 2007. This
    net unrealized gain should be considered in the context of the
    factors discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Cash
    Instruments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 6%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net unrealized loss on level&#160;3 cash instruments was
    $2.59&#160;billion for the year ended November 2007 (which
    included $2.29&#160;billion of unrealized losses on assets and
    $294&#160;million of unrealized losses on liabilities),
    primarily consisting of unrealized losses on subprime
    residential mortgage loans and securities as well as
    non-investment-grade loan commitments, partially offset by
    unrealized gains on principal investments. Level&#160;3 cash
    instruments are frequently hedged with instruments classified in
    level&#160;1 and level&#160;2, and accordingly, gains or losses
    that have been reported in level&#160;3 are frequently offset by
    gains or losses attributable to instruments classified in
    level&#160;1 or level&#160;2 or by gains or losses on derivative
    contracts classified in level&#160;3 of the fair value hierarchy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Derivative
    Contracts</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 6%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The net unrealized gain on level&#160;3 derivative contracts was
    $4.54&#160;billion for the year ended November 2007.
    Level&#160;3 gains and losses on derivative contracts should be
    considered in the context of the following factors:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="90%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    A derivative contract with level&#160;1 and/or level&#160;2
    inputs is classified as a level&#160;3 financial instrument in
    its entirety if it has at least one significant level&#160;3
    input.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    If there is one significant level&#160;3 input, the entire gain
    or loss from adjusting only observable inputs (i.e.,
    level&#160;1 and level 2)&#160;is still classified as
    level&#160;3.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Gains or losses that have been reported in level&#160;3
    resulting from changes in level&#160;1 or level&#160;2 inputs
    are frequently offset by gains or losses attributable to
    instruments classified in level&#160;1 or level&#160;2 or by
    cash instruments reported in level&#160;3 of the fair value
    hierarchy.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 6%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The unrealized gains referenced above principally resulted from
    changes in level&#160;2 inputs, as opposed to changes in
    level&#160;3 inputs.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    129
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November 2007, the changes in the fair value of
    receivables (including securities borrowed and resale
    agreements) for which the fair value option was elected that
    were attributable to changes in instrument-specific credit
    spreads were not material. During 2007, the firm recognized
    gains of $216&#160;million attributable to the observable impact
    of the market&#146;s widening of the firm&#146;s own credit
    spread on liabilities for which the fair value option was
    elected. The firm calculates the impact of its own credit spread
    on liabilities carried at fair value by discounting future cash
    flows at a rate which incorporates the firm&#146;s observable
    credit spreads. As of November 2007, the difference between the
    fair value and the aggregate contractual principal amount of
    both long-term receivables and long-term debt instruments
    (principal and non-principal protected) for which the fair value
    option was elected was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the gains and (losses) included
    in earnings for the year ended November 2007 related to
    financial assets and liabilities for which the firm has elected
    to apply the fair value option under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;155 and
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159. The table does not reflect the impact to
    the firm&#146;s earnings of adopting SFAS&#160;No.&#160;159
    because a significant amount of these gains and losses would
    have also been recognized under previously issued generally
    accepted accounting principles. In addition, instruments for
    which the firm has elected the fair value option are
    economically hedged with instruments accounted for at fair value
    under other generally accepted accounting principles that are
    not reflected in the table below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-left: 6%; margin-right: 0%">

<TD nowrap align="right" valign="bottom">
    18
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">

</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">

    Total&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(4)</SUP>
</DIV>
</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 6%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=456 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes gains of $2.08&#160;billion related to financings
    recorded as a result of certain mortgage securitizations that
    are accounted for as secured financings rather than sales under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140. Changes in the fair value of the secured
    financings are equally offset by changes in the fair value of
    the related mortgage whole loans, which are included within the
    firm&#146;s &#147;Financial instruments owned, at fair
    value&#148; in the consolidated statement of financial condition.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(2)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Consists of investments where the firm would otherwise have
    applied the equity method of accounting as well as securities
    held in GS Bank USA (previously accounted for as
    available-for-sale).
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(3)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Consists of resale and repurchase agreements and securities
    borrowed and loaned within Trading and Principal Investments and
    certificates of deposit issued by GS Bank USA.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(4)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Reported within &#147;Trading and principal investments&#148;
    within the consolidated statements of earnings. The amounts
    exclude contractual interest, which is included in
    &#147;Interest Income&#148; and &#147;Interest Expense,&#148;
    for all instruments other than hybrid financial instruments.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    131
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Credit
    Concentrations</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Credit concentrations may arise from trading, investing,
    underwriting and securities borrowing activities and may be
    impacted by changes in economic, industry or political factors.
    The firm seeks to mitigate credit risk by actively monitoring
    exposures and obtaining collateral as deemed appropriate. While
    the firm&#146;s activities expose it to many different
    industries and counterparties, the firm routinely executes a
    high volume of transactions with counterparties in the financial
    services industry, including brokers and dealers, commercial
    banks, investment funds and other institutional clients,
    resulting in significant credit concentration with respect to
    this industry. In the ordinary course of business, the firm may
    also be subject to a concentration of credit risk to a
    particular counterparty, borrower or issuer.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November 2007 and November 2006, the firm held
    $45.75&#160;billion (4% of total assets) and $46.20&#160;billion
    (6% of total assets), respectively, of U.S. government and
    federal agency obligations (including securities guaranteed by
    the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home
    Loan Mortgage Corporation) included in &#147;Financial
    instruments owned, at fair value&#148; and &#147;Cash and
    securities segregated for regulatory and other purposes&#148; in
    the consolidated statements of financial condition. As of
    November 2007 and November 2006, the firm held
    $31.65&#160;billion (3% of total assets) and $23.64&#160;billion
    (3% of total assets), respectively, of other sovereign
    obligations, principally consisting of securities issued by the
    governments of Japan and the United Kingdom. In addition, as of
    November 2007 and November 2006, $144.92&#160;billion and
    $104.76&#160;billion of the firm&#146;s financial instruments
    purchased under agreements to resell and securities borrowed,
    respectively, were collateralized by U.S. government and federal
    agency obligations. As of November 2007 and 2006,
    $41.26&#160;billion and $38.22&#160;billion of the firm&#146;s
    financial instruments purchased under agreements to resell and
    securities borrowed, respectively, were collateralized by other
    sovereign obligations. As of November 2007 and November 2006,
    the firm did not have credit exposure to any other counterparty
    that exceeded 2% of the firm&#146;s total assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Derivative
    Activities</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Derivative contracts are instruments, such as futures, forwards,
    swaps or option contracts, that derive their value from
    underlying assets, indices, reference rates or a combination of
    these factors. Derivative instruments may be privately
    negotiated contracts, which are often referred to as OTC
    derivatives, or they may be listed and traded on an exchange.
    Derivatives may involve future commitments to purchase or sell
    financial instruments or commodities, or to exchange currency or
    interest payment streams. The amounts exchanged are based on the
    specific terms of the contract with reference to specified
    rates, securities, commodities, currencies or indices.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Certain cash instruments, such as mortgage-backed securities,
    interest-only and principal-only obligations, and indexed debt
    instruments, are not considered derivatives even though their
    values or contractually required cash flows are derived from the
    price of some other security or index. However, certain
    commodity-related contracts are included in the firm&#146;s
    derivatives disclosure, as these contracts may be settled in
    cash or the assets to be delivered under the contract are
    readily convertible into cash.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm enters into derivative transactions to facilitate
    client transactions, to take proprietary positions and as a
    means of risk management. Risk exposures are managed through
    diversification, by controlling position sizes and by entering
    into offsetting positions. For example, the firm may manage the
    risk related to a portfolio of common stock by entering into an
    offsetting position in a related equity-index futures contract.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    132
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm applies hedge accounting under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133
    to certain derivative contracts. The firm uses these derivatives
    to manage certain interest rate and currency exposures,
    including the firm&#146;s net investment in
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.</FONT>
    operations. The firm designates certain interest rate swap
    contracts as fair value hedges. These interest rate swap
    contracts hedge changes in the relevant benchmark interest rate
    (e.g., London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR)), effectively
    converting a substantial portion of the firm&#146;s unsecured
    long-term and certain unsecured short-term borrowings into
    floating rate obligations. See Note&#160;2 for information
    regarding the firm&#146;s accounting policy for foreign currency
    forward contracts used to hedge its net investment in
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">non-U.S.</FONT>
    operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm applies a long-haul method to substantially all of its
    hedge accounting relationships to perform an ongoing assessment
    of the effectiveness of these relationships in achieving
    offsetting changes in fair value or offsetting cash flows
    attributable to the risk being hedged. The firm utilizes a
    dollar-offset method, which compares the change in the fair
    value of the hedging instrument to the change in the fair value
    of the hedged item, excluding the effect of the passage of time,
    to prospectively and retrospectively assess hedge effectiveness.
    The firm&#146;s prospective dollar-offset assessment utilizes
    scenario analyses to test hedge effectiveness via simulations of
    numerous parallel and slope shifts of the relevant yield curve.
    Parallel shifts change the interest rate of all maturities by
    identical amounts. Slope shifts change the curvature of the
    yield curve. For both the prospective assessment, in response to
    each of the simulated yield curve shifts, and the retrospective
    assessment, a hedging relationship is deemed to be effective if
    the fair value of the hedging instrument and the hedged item
    change inversely within a range of 80% to 125%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For fair value hedges, gains or losses on derivative
    transactions are recognized in &#147;Interest expense&#148; in
    the consolidated statements of earnings. The change in fair
    value of the hedged item attributable to the risk being hedged
    is reported as an adjustment to its carrying value and is
    subsequently amortized into interest expense over its remaining
    life. Gains or losses related to hedge ineffectiveness for all
    hedges are generally included in &#147;Interest expense.&#148;
    These gains or losses and the component of gains or losses on
    derivative transactions excluded from the assessment of hedge
    effectiveness (e.g., the effect of the passage of time on fair
    value hedges of the firm&#146;s borrowings) were not material to
    the firm&#146;s results of operations for the years ended
    November&#160;2007, November&#160;2006 and November&#160;2005.
    Gains and losses on derivatives used for trading purposes are
    included in &#147;Trading and principal investments&#148; in the
    consolidated statements of earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The fair value of the firm&#146;s derivative contracts is
    reflected net of cash paid or received pursuant to credit
    support agreements and is reported on a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">net-by-counterparty</FONT>
    basis in the firm&#146;s consolidated statements of financial
    condition when management believes a legal right of setoff
    exists under an enforceable netting agreement. The fair value of
    derivative financial instruments, computed in accordance with
    the firm&#146;s netting policy, is set forth below:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-left: 6%; margin-right: 0%">
<TABLE border="0" width="94%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The fair value of derivatives accounted for as qualifying hedges
    under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133 consisted of $5.12&#160;billion and
    $2.66&#160;billion in assets as of November 2007 and November
    2006, respectively, and $354&#160;million and $551&#160;million
    in liabilities as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    133
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm also has embedded derivatives that have been bifurcated
    from related borrowings under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;133. Such
    derivatives, which are classified in unsecured short-term and
    unsecured long-term borrowings, had a carrying value of
    $463&#160;million and $1.13&#160;billion (excluding the debt
    host contract) as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively. See Notes&#160;4 and 5 for further information
    regarding the firm&#146;s unsecured borrowings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Securitization
    Activities</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm securitizes commercial and residential mortgages, home
    equity and auto loans, government and corporate bonds and other
    types of financial assets. The firm acts as underwriter of the
    beneficial interests that are sold to investors. The firm
    derecognizes financial assets transferred in securitizations
    provided it has relinquished control over such assets.
    Transferred assets are accounted for at fair value prior to
    securitization. Net revenues related to these underwriting
    activities are recognized in connection with the sales of the
    underlying beneficial interests to investors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm may retain interests in securitized financial assets,
    primarily in the form of senior or subordinated securities,
    including residual interests. Retained interests are accounted
    for at fair value and are included in &#147;Total financial
    instruments owned, at fair value&#148; in the consolidated
    statements of financial condition.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the year ended November 2007, the firm securitized
    $81.40&#160;billion of financial assets ($24.95&#160;billion of
    residential mortgages, $19.50&#160;billion of commercial
    mortgages and $36.95&#160;billion of other financial assets,
    primarily in connection with collateralized debt and loan
    obligations (CDOs and CLOs)). During the year ended November
    2006, the firm securitized $103.92&#160;billion of financial
    assets ($67.73&#160;billion of residential mortgages,
    $12.78&#160;billion of commercial mortgages and
    $23.41&#160;billion of other financial assets, primarily in
    connection with CDOs and CLOs). Cash flows received on retained
    interests were approximately $705&#160;million and
    $801&#160;million for the years ended November 2007 and November
    2006, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November 2007 and November 2006, the firm held
    $4.57&#160;billion and $7.08&#160;billion of retained interests,
    respectively, from these securitization activities, including
    $2.72&#160;billion and $5.18&#160;billion, respectively, held in
    QSPEs.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    134
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the weighted average key economic
    assumptions used in measuring the fair value of the firm&#146;s
    retained interests and the sensitivity of this fair value to
    immediate adverse changes of 10% and 20% in those assumptions:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 6%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Anticipated credit losses are computed only on positions for
    which expected credit loss is a key assumption in the
    determination of fair value or positions for which expected
    credit loss is not reflected within the discount rate.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(2)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The impacts of adverse change take into account credit mitigants
    incorporated in the retained interests, including
    over-collateralization and subordination provisions.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(3)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes $905&#160;million and $1.26&#160;billion as of November
    2007 and November 2006, respectively, of retained interests
    related to transfers of securitized assets that were accounted
    for as secured financings rather than sales under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;140.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(4)</SUP>&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Includes retained interests in bonds and other types of
    financial assets that are not subject to prepayment risk.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The preceding table does not give effect to the offsetting
    benefit of other financial instruments that are held to mitigate
    risks inherent in these retained interests. Changes in fair
    value based on an adverse variation in assumptions generally
    cannot be extrapolated because the relationship of the change in
    assumptions to the change in fair value is not usually linear.
    In addition, the impact of a change in a particular assumption
    is calculated independently of changes in any other assumption.
    In practice, simultaneous changes in assumptions might magnify
    or counteract the sensitivities disclosed above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the retained interests described above, the firm
    also held interests in residential mortgage QSPEs purchased in
    connection with secondary market-making activities. These
    purchased interests approximated $6&#160;billion and
    $8&#160;billion as of November 2007 and November 2006,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    135
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of November 2007 and November 2006, the firm held mortgage
    servicing rights with a fair value of $93&#160;million and
    $62&#160;million, respectively, substantially all of which were
    retained in connection with residential mortgage
    securitizations. These servicing assets represent the
    firm&#146;s right to receive a future stream of cash flows
    associated with the firm&#146;s obligation to service
    residential mortgages. The fair value of mortgage servicing
    rights will fluctuate in response to changes in certain economic
    variables, such as interest rates, loan prepayment assumptions
    and default rates. The firm determines the fair value of
    mortgage servicing rights by using valuation models that
    incorporate these variables in quantifying anticipated cash
    flows related to servicing activities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Variable
    Interest Entities (VIEs)</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm, in the ordinary course of business, retains interests
    in VIEs in connection with its securitization activities. The
    firm also purchases and sells variable interests in VIEs, which
    primarily issue mortgage-backed and other asset-backed
    securities, CDOs and CLOs, in connection with its market-making
    activities and makes investments in and loans to VIEs that hold
    performing and nonperforming debt, equity, real estate,
    power-related and other assets. In addition, the firm utilizes
    VIEs to provide investors with principal-protected notes,
    credit-linked notes and asset-repackaged notes designed to meet
    their objectives.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    VIEs generally purchase assets by issuing debt and equity
    instruments. In certain instances, the firm provides guarantees
    to VIEs or holders of variable interests in VIEs. In such cases,
    the maximum exposure to loss included in the tables set forth
    below is the notional amount of such guarantees. Such amounts do
    not represent anticipated losses in connection with these
    guarantees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The firm&#146;s variable interests in VIEs include senior and
    subordinated debt; loan commitments; limited and general
    partnership interests; preferred and common stock; interest
    rate, foreign currency, equity, commodity and credit
    derivatives; guarantees; and residual interests in
    mortgage-backed and asset-backed securitization vehicles, CDOs
    and CLOs. The firm&#146;s exposure to the obligations of VIEs is
    generally limited to its interests in these entities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following tables set forth total assets in nonconsolidated
    VIEs in which the firm holds significant variable interests and
    the firm&#146;s maximum exposure to loss associated with these
    variable interests. The firm has aggregated nonconsolidated VIEs
    based on principal business activity, as reflected in the first
    column. The nature of the firm&#146;s variable interests can
    take different forms, as described in the columns under maximum
    exposure to loss.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    136
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">THE GOLDMAN SACHS
    GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">NOTES TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 5%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    These tables do not give effect to the benefit of any offsetting
    financial instruments that are held to mitigate risks related to
    the firm&#146;s interests in nonconsolidated VIEs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="39%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
